author: Jasper Hamill
title: Legendary British inventor Sir Clive Sinclair to star in crowd funded documentary
text:
He's the mysterious tech tycoon whose famous products were loved by millions - and sometimes mocked by just as many people.
Now the British computer pioneer Sir Clive Sinclair is set to star in a new documentary which will shed light on a life which has largely been led outside the limelight.
Inventor Sinclair designed the ZX Spectrum, which was designed to be cheap enough for any household to afford, as well as the C5, a futuristic vehicle which failed to catch the imagination of the British public.
A production house called The Digital Media Factory is hoping to raise £75,000 on Indiegogo to make a film called Sinclair - From Vision To Vega.
The title comes from the name of the business mogul's most recent project, a reissued ZX Spectrum called The Vega which comes pre-loaded with 1,000 games and smashed its own £100,000 Indiegogo funding goal in just two days. The Spectrum Vega is a faithful reproduction of the classic computer
Iain Lee, former host of the Celebrity Big Brother spin off Bit On The Psych, will host the documentary.
Having appeared in the cult show Thumb Bandits and shot a history of the British games industry, Lee is well-known among tech fans.
He told Mirror Online he was excited about making the film, although his parents forbade him from owning a Spectrum back in the 1980s.
"I find computer games more relaxing than Big Brother," he said. Getty Retro: A Sinclair ZX Spectrum computer Console
"They are less stress inducing and the characters tend to be friendlier. "
He told us he was confident the documentary would hit its crowdfunding target.
"There is a lot of affection for retro computer games," he said.
"Clive Sinclair is also a fascinating figure and I don't think he had the respect he deserves as an eccentric British innovator."
The crowdfunding campaign will conclude in 60 days and has already raised £1,366 after launching yesterday.
Old school rules: The Lords Of Midnight on the ZX Spectrum
Paul Andrews, producer with The Digital Media Factory, added: "We don’t want to make just another talking heads documentary.
"Nor do we want to produce a dry history lesson, so while it will explore the innovations within their historical context, we'll also test, trial, and play with the devices themselves with the irreverence they deserve."
